Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Judith Lomax, (1774-1828), a poet from the early 19th century, made a significant contribution to American literature with her collection "The Notes of an American Lyre," published in 1813. Born in Port Tobacco, Maryland, Lomax was one of the first women in the United States to publish a book of poetry under her own name. "The Notes of an American Lyre" is notable for its patriotic themes and reflections on the young nation's ideals and struggles.

Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Jennie Booth Moton, (1879-1942), was a prominent African American educator and activist in the early 20th century. She dedicated her life to improving educational opportunities for African Americans in the South. Moton attended Hampton Institute (now Hampton University) and later became a teacher at Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. There, she met and married Robert Russa Moton, who would become the second president of Tuskegee after Booker T. Washington.

Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Woman with Hat - observes the arc of history and the iconic women who transformed Gloucester over the last 250 years. The Suffragette represents the first women in Gloucester to vote.

Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Kacey Carneal, (1925-2022), is a renowned artist and community figure from Gloucester, Virginia, whose vibrant work and dedication to the arts significantly impacted the local cultural landscape. Carneal lived and painted in Gloucester for nearly 50 years, her artistic journey began in her youth and flourished over the decades. Her distinctive style, often through bold colors and expressive brushstrokes, captures the essence of Virginia life and nature.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Mary Shipko is a notable figure in Gloucester, Virginia, known for her significant contributions to aviation and her inspiring life story. Born in 1944, Shipko developed a passion for flying at a young age and went on to become one of the first female commercial airline pilots in the United States. Her career in aviation began in the 1960s when she earned her private pilot's license, followed by her commercial license and instrument rating. Shipko faced numerous challenges and discrimination in the male-dominated field of aviation but persevered to achieve her dreams. She flew for several major airlines during her career, breaking barriers and paving the way for future generations of women in aviation. After retiring from commercial flying, Shipko settled in Gloucester, where she became an active member of the community.

Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Margaret Ann Tunner, (1917-2009), born in 1917, was a pioneering American aviator who made significant contributions to military aviation during World War II and beyond. Known as the "Mother of Strategic Airlift," Tunner played a crucial role in developing air transport operations for the U.S. military. She began her career as a civilian pilot and flight instructor before joining the Women Airforce Service Pilots (WASP) during World War II. After the war, she continued her aviation career and became one of the first women to achieve the rank of colonel in the U.S. Air Force. Tunner was instrumental in establishing efficient air transport systems, particularly during the Berlin Airlift of 1948-1949, where she worked alongside her husband, Lieutenant General William H. Tunner. Throughout her career, she advocated for women's roles in aviation and military service, breaking numerous barriers and setting records in the process. Margaret Ann Tunner's legacy continues to inspire aviators and military personnel, particularly women in aerospace careers. Tunner retired to the beautiful Ware Neck area of Gloucester County.

Tourism Blog - New Mural on Main Street Celebrates 250 Years of Women's Contributions - Irene Morgan, (1917-2007), born Irene Amos in 1917, was a pivotal figure in the American civil rights movement, though her name is often overlooked in historical accounts. In July 1944, eleven years before Rosa Parks' famous act of defiance, Morgan refused to give up her bus seat to a white passenger in Virginia. When arrested, she fought back physically and was charged with resisting arrest and violating Virginia's segregation laws. Morgan's case, Morgan v. Virginia, went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court, which ruled in 1946 that segregation in interstate travel was unconstitutional. This landmark decision became a crucial precedent in the fight against segregation and inspired the Freedom Rides of 1961. Despite facing significant personal risks, Morgan's courageous stand helped pave the way for future civil rights victories. Her actions demonstrated the power of individual resistance against systemic racism and contributed significantly to the legal dismantling of Jim Crow laws. In 2001, President Bill Clinton awarded Morgan the Presidential Citizens Medal for her contribution to the civil rights movement.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Concerts On The Green - Summer Series in Gloucester - A Perfect Setting Gloucester Court Circle, with its historic charm and scenic beauty, provides the perfect backdrop for these summer concerts. As the sun sets and the evening cools, the green space becomes a cozy haven where families spread out picnic blankets, friends gather on lawn chairs, and children dance freely to the music. The ambiance is further enhanced by the surrounding historic buildings, adding a touch of nostalgia and elegance to the event.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - La Promenade Beyond the Frame
image:image.image:caption: Location: Fairfield Foundation 6783 Main St, Gloucester, VA 23061 La Promenade is a captivating statue that captures the essence of a leisurely stroll in a park. This statue was inspired by Paris Street: A Rainy Day by artist Gustave Callebotte. The statue depicts a couple, elegantly dressed, walking hand in hand with a sense of grace and romance.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Creating Celebrating the Familiar
image:image.image:caption: Location: The Coke Building 6688 Main Street, Gloucester, VA 23061 The Celebrating the Familiar collection by Seward Johnson is a remarkable series of sculptures that pays homage to the ordinary moments and everyday experiences that often go unnoticed.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Time For Fun Beyond the Frame
image:image.image:caption: Location: Yolanda’s On Main 6658 Main St, Gloucester, VA 23061 This statue was inspired by “Country Dance” by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, a prominent French artist from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, who is known for his remarkable ability to capture the beauty of everyday life. One of his notable works is "Country Dance," a painting that showcases his mastery of capturing movement and human interaction. In this piece, Renoir depicts a lively scene of people engaged in a traditional country dance. The figures are depicted with vibrant colors and soft brushstrokes, creating a sense of energy and liveliness.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Weekend Painter Celebrating the Familiar
image:image.image:caption: Location: Kelsick Market 6632 Main St, Gloucester, VA 23061 The Weekend Painter is a sculpture that celebrates the joy of artistic expression. The statue depicts a man, dressed in casual attire, holding a paintbrush and palette in his hands. With a focused and determined expression, he is captured in the act of painting, fully immersed in his creative process.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - A Turn of the Century Beyond the Frame
image:image.image:caption: Location: Hudson Building 6582 Main Street, Gloucester, VA 23061 This statue was inspired by "Dance at Bougival", a captivating painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, a renowned French artist from the 19th and early 20th centuries. The painting depicts a couple engaged in a lively dance at a popular dance hall in Bougival, a suburb of Paris. Renoir's brushstrokes are loose and vibrant, capturing the movement and energy of the dancers. The figures are elegantly dressed, with the woman wearing a flowing pink dress and the man in a formal suit. Renoir's use of light and color adds depth and warmth. "Dance at Bougival" is a testament to Renoir's ability to capture the essence of human interaction and the beauty of social gatherings through his masterful technique and keen observation.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Inner World/Outer World Celebrating the Familiar
image:image.image:caption: Location: Corner of Duval Ave 6586 Main Street, Gloucester, VA 23061 This statue is not new to Main Street but was sent for a refreshing makeover and is back. The community knows this statue as “Fred” and we feel it fits perfectly! Make sure to stop and sit for a photo with Fred and check out his updated Newspaper!

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Whispering Close Beyond the Frame
image:image.image:caption: Location: Dr. Timothy A. Leigh, D.D.S - 6661 Main St, Gloucester, VA 23061 This statue was inspired by "City Dance" (Danse à la ville) a captivating painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, a renowned French artist from the 19th and early 20th centuries. The painting depicts a lively scene of people dancing in an urban setting, capturing the vibrant energy and joy of social gatherings. Renoir's brushstrokes are loose and fluid, creating a sense of movement and spontaneity. The figures in the painting are elegantly dressed, showcasing the fashionable attire of the time. Renoir's use of light and color adds depth and warmth to the scene, enhancing the overall atmosphere of celebration and merriment.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Eye of the Beholder Beyond the Frame
image:image.image:caption: Location: Gloucester Historic Courthouse Circle 6504 Main Street, Gloucester, VA 23061 This work was inspired by Edouard Manet's painting 'Chez Pèré Lathuille' (1879). The painting depicts a bustling scene in a Parisian café, capturing the lively atmosphere and social interactions of the time.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Enchanting Seward Johnson Statues on Main Street in Gloucester, VA - Follow Me Beyond the Frame
image:image.image:caption: Location: The Gloucester Museum of History 6539 Main Street, Gloucester, VA 23061 This statue was inspired by "The Fifer" or "Young Flautist", a notable painting created by the renowned French painter Édouard Manet in 1866. The painting depicts a young boy dressed in a military uniform, holding a flute and standing against a neutral background. The composition is characterized by bold brushstrokes and a strong contrast between light and dark tones. Manet's attention to detail is evident in the intricate rendering of the boy's uniform and the subtle nuances of his facial expression. The painting is a testament to Manet's innovative approach to art, as he challenged traditional techniques and conventions of his time. "The Fifer" remains an iconic piece in Manet's body of work, showcasing his mastery of capturing the human form and his unique artistic vision.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Fiorello Ristorante Italiano | 4938 George Washington Memorial Hwy, Hayes, VA 23072 | Monday - Closed Tues-Thurs 11AM-2:30PM 5PM-9PM Fri-Sat 11AM-2:30PM 5PM-9:30PM Sun 11AM-2:30PM and 5PM-8PM | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Indulge in the best of Italian cuisine at our restaurant, where we serve crisp, freshly made salads and one-of-a-kind garlic knots, all paired perfectly with our finest wine selections, including white and red wines. Our full bar offers daily happy hour specials, adding to the convivial atmosphere. Don’t forget to save room for our sensational desserts, which will take your taste buds on a journey to the heart of Italy. Come enjoy our superior quality meals today!

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Doodles Donuts & Cafe | 4744 George Washington Memorial Hwy Hayes VA, 23072 | Wed &Thurs: 5:00 AM-2:00 PM Friday: 4:00 AM-2:00 PM Sat & Sun: 7:00 AM-2:00 PM | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: We are a locally owned donut shop that specializes in yeast donuts! Our flavors rotate daily, and our daily menu can be found on our Facebook and Instagram sites, but we try to meet any flavor needs you might have. You must try the Maple Bacon donuts! Special: Mention Restaurant Week and receive 10 % off of a dozen

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week
Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week
Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week
Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Lulu Birds Kitchen | 6553 Main Street | Wed-Sat 4:30 -9:00PM |
image:image.image:caption: Lulu Birds Kitchen is elevated Southern comfort food. All the regional dishes you love and new ones you haven’t tried, but with more flavors and dimensions. Reimagined traditional dishes and drinks that are unforgettable. Restaurant Week Menu Apps- Herbed Rocotta with Roasted olive Tapenade / Smoky moonshine BBQ chicken flatbread Entrees- Country style Duck Confit / Smoked Vegetarian Lasagna Reservations are highly recommended but walk-ins are welcome ***Photograph does not represent restaurant week special

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Creekside Market | 6824 Colemans Crossing Ave. Hayes, Va. 23072 | 2/26 Closed 2/27-3/2 10AM-7PM | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Enjoy a seat in our cozy Café for dining in or for carry out. We have a Market for grab and go items. We specialize in catering and have a private event space on premise. “We love our guests and our community and making great food is what we love to do.”

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week
Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week

Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Sweet Tooth Café | 6566 Main Street Gloucester, 23061 | Mon-Fri 10-7pm. Sat 10-6pm | ‍‍ We are a locally owned café on Main Street that provides amazing sandwiches, soups, salads, lattes and a full dessert bar. Reservations Encouraged
image:image.image:caption: Specials: An appetizer, meal & dessert combo for two.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Zoll Vineyards | 10309 Vineyard Road | Wed, Thurs, Fri 12-6 pm, Sat & Sun 12-8 pm | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Zoll Vineyards is a chef owned boutique winery owned by Chef Frank Zoll. Wine, sangria, cider, & mead are available to pair with a full food menu in our tavern style tasting room. Restaurant Week Menu: Cornbread Donuts on our Breadcuterie, Lemon Rose’ Boozey Pudding in white chocolate cups, Warm Cranberry Mulled Cider, Chesapeake- Crab cake & steak sandwich, Grilled Strawberry Brie, Big Corned Beef- Half pound corned beef horseradish mustard and swiss on rye with the best pickles in Virginia! Specials: Breadcuterie included with entrée purchase & 10% off specials and cocktails

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Wondering Gypzs Kitchen | 6655 main street | 11AM to 8PM | We are Main Streets Sub, Burger and Gyro shop. Of course never forget the crispy fries with our gypz cheese. We are serve our tasties to go with plenty of room to eat in if you care to feed your happiness here. The sweet peanut butter confection fudge or cheesecake make for a nice treat. See the menu and order at wonderinggypzs.com Special: 10 % off entire pickup order that includes a desert, for length of restaurant week. Doesn't include delivery orders.
image:image.image:caption: Our Gyros have a traditional flavor using lamb and beef for an authentic taste. All our foods are packed full of real flavors, passion and love.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Ann’s Family Dining | 6545 Market Drive | Tues - Sat 6:00 am - 7:00 pm, Sun 6:00 am - 4:00 pm | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Ann’s Family Diner is a locally owned, family friendly diner located in the Shoppes at Gloucester shopping center, serving the area for over 40 years! “Our number one goal is repeat customers” Visit during Restaurant week and indulge in our famous Hamburger Steak! Specials: Our famous Hamburger steak with onions and gravy, choice of 2 sides, Texas toast, tea or soda and our very own home made bread pudding with a scoop of ice cream for just $22.95

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Mobjack Tavern| 5036 George Washington Memorial Hwy |Open Every Day 11:30 AM to 9:00 PM | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: “At Mobjack Tavern we're always focused on providing the freshest ingredients. Using produce from local farmers and seafood from our local fishermen you'll taste what fresh means in all our dishes. We're also proud to serve all natural Boarshead meats.”

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Kelsick Market | 6706 Main Street Gloucester | Tuesday- Friday 11-5:30 Saturday 11-5 | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Kelsick Specialty Market is the perfect place to find all types of foods, beverages and unique gifts. Come by and discover shelves filled with gourmet foods, freezers full of prepared foods, cold cases loaded with specialty beverages, cheeses and meats and an exceptional catering service. Kelsick supplies hundreds of wines and craft beers to Gloucester Main Street and have a wonderful little café inside where they serve charcuterie & wine by the glass. Special: A Charcuterie & wine bundle for two

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Damon & Company | 7104 George Washington Memorial Highway | Sun-Wed 6AM-1AM Thurs-Sat 6AM-2PM | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Established in 1991, here at Damon and Company, we've been serving the community with pride, offering a delightful experience in breakfast, fresh seafood, and hand-cut steaks. Our commitment to quality cuisine and excellent service has made us a beloved spot for locals and visitors alike. What sets us apart is not only our delectable menu but also our dedication to being a hub for vibrant entertainment. From hosting the hottest local acts to creating an energetic atmosphere at night, Damon and Company transforms into a lively destination for fun and enjoyment. By day, we transition seamlessly into a calm, family-oriented restaurant where you can gather with your loved ones in a relaxed setting. We believe in offering a diverse experience, catering to both the spirited night owls and those seeking a tranquil daytime retreat. Special: Mention Restaurant Week and receive 10% off!

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Short Lane Ice Cream Co | 6721 George Washington Mem Hwy | 11 am - 8:30 pm | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: We are a family owned business and make our ice cream on site with fresh cream and ingredients! We provide samples so you can be sure of your choice! Honey Lavender is a must! All of our flavors are popular. Our traditional flavors like chocolate, vanilla, strawberry, butter pecan, or coffee (to name a few) are local favorites. Honey Lavender, black raspberry, coffee crunch, and Cinnamon Toast Crunch are super popular! We are best known for our great rotating flavors, awesome customer service, and a history lesson in our building with antiques and articles. Special: 5% discount with mention of Gloucester Restaurant Week

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week
Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week

Hwy. | 7AM-2PM 7 days a week | ‍‍ Offering a full menu all day, breakfast all day, home made specials, desserts, fresh local seafood! Call ahead seating is available, and suggested for parties of 5 or more, but we do not take reservations usually.
image:image.image:caption: Special : 10% off your entire bill if you mention Gloucester restaurant week

Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Olivia’s In The Village | 6597 Main St | Mon-Thurs 6 am - 9 pm Fri 6 am- 10pm Sat 7am- 10pm & Sun 7am-9pm | ‍‍
image:image.image:caption: Olivia's in the Village is on Gloucester's historic Main Street. Offering Pasta, Steaks & Seafood, enjoy Great Family Dining! Come visit and receive a family welcome while dining on fabulous food - timeless recipes that have been passed down through generations. Restaurant Week Special: 3 for $30 3 Courses - Choose one appetizer, entrée and dessert from their full menu. Beverages are additional

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - 2024 Restaurant Week - Baked | 1759 George Washington Memorial Highway, Gloucester Point | Wednesday - Saturday 10AM-4PM Sunday 11Am-3PM | ‍‍ We are a bake shop that carries baked goods such as cupcakes, brownies, cookies, etc. We also do custom cake orders!
image:image.image:caption: Restaurant Week Menu: Variety of cheesecake flavors Specials: 10% off cheesecake by the slice

image:image.image:caption: Family owned and operated Thai and Sushi fine dining restaurant best known for their amazing Pad Thai and fried rice! Great environment to make you feel like family! Special : Receive a FREE desert with the purchase of an entrée with the mention of restaurant week!

image:image.image:title: Tourism Blog - Exploring the Historical Tapestry: Pocahontas and the Heartbeat of Gloucester, Virginia - Pocahontas, born Matoaka, was a paramount chief's daughter of the Powhatan Confederacy, a Native American group in the early 17th century. Her journey, intertwined with the arrival of English settlers, unfolded against the backdrop of what would become Gloucester County.
image:image.image:caption: Pocahontas by Simon van de Passe (1616)

image:image.image:caption: Nature takes on a serene beauty at Beaverdam Park. Take a winter stroll along the trails, where the bare branches create a lacy canopy against the crisp sky. Bundle up and savor the tranquility that surrounds the park. Gloucester provides a total of 7 parks plus our very own State Park. Machicomoco State Park is a beautiful place to visit and enjoy the views of the York River, Timber Neck House, and learn the history of the land. This park has nature trails, a bike path around the entire park, and picnic areas. Photograph By : Michael Wilkes at Beaverdam Park December 2023

image:image.image:caption: The cabins and cottages here at Camp Cardinal are perfect for up to 6 people and provide a smaller home away from home experience. image:image.image:caption: “Recreational yurts are a modern adaptation of an ancient nomadic shelter. Functionally speaking, they’re a cross between a tent and a cabin. image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - Film Premiere: RIA: The Divergent Daffodil - The Fine Arts Museum of Gloucester not only showcases significant works of art but also serves as a hub for cultural activities and events, contributing to the vibrant arts scene in the region (thecookfoundation.org). This prestigious venue is proud to host the premiere of “RIA: The Divergent Daffodil,” a documentary that aligns perfectly with the museum’s mission to inspire and enrich the community through the arts. The event will include a screening of the film, a Q&A session with the director Sean Clinkscales and the documentary’s subject Maria Lee-Driver, promising an engaging and enriching experience for all attendees.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - Tea & Tranquility at Holly Knoll - Tea & Tranquility: A High Noon Tea Gathering
image:image.image:caption: is an elegant event designed to transport guests into a realm of relaxation and refined indulgence. Picture a serene setting, perhaps a beautifully landscaped garden or a cozy, sunlit conservatory, where guests are greeted with the gentle fragrance of freshly brewed tea and the soothing melodies of soft instrumental music. As attendees arrive, they're welcomed with a selection of premium teas from around the world, carefully curated to cater to diverse tastes and preferences. From delicate floral blends to robust black teas, each offering promises a unique sensory experience.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - Bourbon, Bacon & Beer Fest - Indulge in the perfect trio of flavor at our Bourbon, Bacon & Beer Fest! Unlimited craft beer, 10 Bourbon tastings & 1/2 lb Bacon!
image:image.image:caption: Get Ready to Savor the Ultimate Flavor Experience at the Bourbon Bacon & Beer Fest! Indulge your taste buds and rock out to the rhythm of fantastic tunes at the most tantalizing event of the season: the Bourbon Bacon & Beer Fest! Join us for an unforgettable celebration packed with a fusion of flavors that will tantalize your senses. Here's what's in store for you: **Live Music by Rip Tide**: Get ready to groove to the rhythm as Rip Tide takes the stage, delivering electrifying performances that will keep you dancing all day long! **Craft Beer**: Unlimited craft beer from local microbreweries! **Bacon Delights**: Indulge in savory bacon delights as you create your mouthwatering bacon masterpiece with your 1/2 pound of bacon and a savory array of toppings to make it truly yours! **Food Trucks** Don't miss out on the culinary magic as you prepare to embark on a culinary adventure like no other with the finest food trucks in the region. **Virginia Distilleries**: 10 Tasting tickets to savor the smooth, rich flavors of Virginia's finest bourbons and spirits, crafted with care and precision by local distilleries. Whether you're a bourbon enthusiast or a whiskey connoisseur, you'll find something to delight your taste buds at our distillery showcase. **On-Site Parking**: Enjoy hassle-free access to the event with convenient on-site parking available for all attendees. Spend less time searching for parking and more time indulging in the festivities

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - Charcuterie Board Class at Zoll Vineyards - Join Chef Zoll and learn how to make your own delicious charcuterie boards! Please come early to enjoy food and beverage menu prior to the class start.

Tourism Events - Spray Paint & Sip at Zoll Vineyards - Grab your partner, friends and family for Zoll Vineyards’ Paint and Sip! This is a family friendly event! The theme for this night is Spray Paint and Sip--- You will learn how to create your own unique painting with spray paint, led by Don DeWolf- who is an amazing local artist! Come early to get drinks & food before class! Reserve a table if you have a large group by emailing Frank@Zollvineyards.com after purchasing tickets.
image:image.image:caption: Tickets are non-refundable, unless event is cancelled. 18+ to eat & paint, 21+ to drink.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - Find LOVE on Main
image:image.image:caption: Can you find LOVE on Main Street? Register today for the 2024 Find LOVE on Main Street Scavenger Hunt presented by Gloucester Main Street Association. Teams of 2 will meet at the Gloucester Brewing Co to check in and receive your first clue. This hunt lasts from 11AM-3PM (all hunters must be done by 3PM) Once you figure out the each location you will enter the establishment, find the "Virginia is For Lovers" logo, take a photo ( this is a must!), and then show to the store staff to receive your next clue. Once all clues have been completed you will head back to Gloucester Brewing Co to receive your price!

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - Snow Globe Soirée: A Valentines Day Experience - Perfect addition to Your Valentines Day Celebration!
image:image.image:caption: Imagine dining in your own private, cozy igloo surrounded by stunning winter scenery. The igloo is heated and fully furnished, complete with Bluetooth speaker, comfortable seating, and all the amenities you need for a luxurious farm dining experience. A talented group of chefs will prepare a delicious, pre-fixe gourmet meal just for you, featuring the finest ingredients and flavors of the season. From appetizers to entrees to desserts, you'll be treated to a culinary feast that will tantalize the taste buds and indulge the appetite.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - LIVE MUSIC by Ben Long - Join us for great music, brews, & even better company!
image:image.image:caption: “Virginia native Ben Long was a guitar player first. From the age of 14 he became obsessed with the likes of Jimi Hendrix, SRV, John Frusciante, and John Mayer. It wasn’t until the age of 18 during a summer semester at Berklee College of Music that he started to hone in on the craft of songwriting. During his time in Boston, his influences became widely broadened. Whether it’s the guitar playing of the 60s, the lyrical sense of folk, or that new age flair of alternative and indie music…”

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - 1 day Basic Blacksmithing 2024 Experience - 1 Day- Basic Blacksmithing with The Village Blacksmith
image:image.image:caption: In this 1 day intensive Blacksmithing course, aspiring smiths will learn the basic essential techniques to be able to produce multiple items. Though we will adhere to the course syllabus there will be time for some additional skills and topics.. This is an intensive and immersive class and we will jump right into it, hands on, learning through creating. Students will learn and refine their skills with the end goal of creating multiple projects they will take home. Registration for these classes end two days prior to event date.

image:image.image:title: Tourism Events - 3rd Annual Timberneck Turkey Trot 5K Run/Walk
image:image.image:caption: 3rd Annual Timberneck Turkey Trot 5K Run/Walk There will be a Kids Fun Run ( 800M dash) before the 5k that will start at 9:30AM. This is the perfect event to enter if you love coming to the park or have been wanting to visit! The park is a beautiful area to explore and get in a few miles! All race proceeds help fund the restoration of the Timberneck House, the c.1800 Catlett family home overlooking the York River in Machicomoco State Park. The Timberneck House is undergoing renovation to become a place for learning, lodging, and exploring Virginia's Middle Peninsula.

image:image.image:title: Museum Exhibits & Events - Dr. Walter Reed (1851-1902)- Conqueror of the Yellow Fever
image:image.image:caption: Located at the intersection of routes 616 and 614 is a small mid-19th century building authentically furnished. It is significant because it represents the early small rural dwellings once so common to Tidewater Virginia. One-story, three-bay, frame gable-roofed dwelling covered with white weather boarding and set on short brick piers.

image:image.image:title: Museum Exhibits & Events - Dr. Walter Reed (1851-1902)- Conqueror of the Yellow Fever
image:image.image:caption: Walter Reed was born on September 13, 1851, in a small country home at Belroi, Gloucester County, Virginia. He was the last of five children of the Reverend Lemuel Sutton Reed and his wife Pharaba White. His father was a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, who moved every two years to a different circuit of the church. It was during a two-year service (1851-1852) that Walter was born. He studied medicine at the University of Virginia.

image:image.image:caption: “Camp Burke’s Mill Pond is 40-acres of sheer Gloucester County beauty,” said Robert Kelly, Gloucester County’s Museums Coordinator. “It is known for its rolling hills, forest, and gorgeous water views. image:image.image:title: Clean Community Blog - The Vital Role of Pollinators in Gloucester County, Virginia - Wrapping up Pollinator Week with the Hummingbird! Did you know that hummingbirds are the smallest migrating bird? Their average weight is less than a nickel. Hummingbirds name comes from the humming noise their wings make as they beat fast. Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backwards. These amazing little birds are important pollinators for many flowering plants in North and South America. Remember when feeding hummingbirds it is important to clean your feeder often and only use a simple sugar syrup (4 parts water to 1 part sugar) free of honey, food coloring or other impurities. Having a feeder doesn't draw the hummingbird from its natural food, but rather gives the bird a quick burst of energy.

Clean Community Blog - The Vital Role of Pollinators in Gloucester County, Virginia - Sphinx Moth (Other common names are Hummingbird or Hawk Moth) have long, pointed abdomens and plump bodies that are covered with long hairs. Their wingspan can range from 1-6 inches and their wings come in a variety of shapes and colors. They have a very long tongue that they use to drink nectar, it can uncoil up to 11 inches! The Sphinx moth caterpillars are often called hornworms, because they usually have a set of pointed horns on their rear end. You may find them munching on your tomato plants. Remove them and place them on a Virginia Creeper and they will be happy. Like hummingbirds, sphinx moths are known for hovering over flowers and have a tail that opens like a fan while they are collecting nectar. Some can move sideways and stop in midair. They are some of the fastest flying insects in the world, known for their hawk like speed they can reach up to 30mph.

Clean Community Blog - 2024 Green Grants Award Gloucester County Clean Community - The grant also allows for a flowerbed with some native plants to attract local pollinators will be added to further beautify the area, as well as planting wildflower seeds around the edge of the park. The Gloucester Clean Community initiative has always been dedicated to enhancing the quality of life in our county through environmental stewardship, education, and community involvement. This project exemplifies our mission by combining elements of recreation, community engagement, and environmental enhancement. By revamping the half-pipe, we are not only improving a physical structure but also fostering a sense of community pride and ownership.

Clean Community Blog - 2024 Green Grants Award Gloucester County Clean Community - We are thrilled to announce that Gloucester Clean Community has been awarded a grant from Keep America Beautiful, aimed at revitalizing the beloved half-pipe at Browns Park. This grant will provide a fresh and enjoyable space for our local skaters and BMX enthusiasts. Browns Park has long been a cornerstone for outdoor activities and community gatherings in Gloucester. The half-pipe, in particular, has been a popular feature among youth and adults alike, offering a thrilling spot for practicing tricks and enjoying the exhilaration of skateboarding and BMX riding. However, with years of wear and tear, the half-pipe has been in need of a makeover.

image:image.image:title: Clean Community Blog - International Clean Coastal Day Recap!
image:image.image:caption: Being a part of a Clean Gloucester event is super easy! Sometimes they are held in a specific location like the International Coastal Cleanup or sometimes volunteers can pick their own location to clean. This is great if groups want to clean up their roads leading to their neighborhood or a location you love driving through but hate to see litter. While you are cleaning you will fill out a form similar to the one here and turn that in to the Clean Community Coordinator. She will then add up all the totals and record the amount of trash either by pieces or weight. The Fall 2022 Clean Gloucester Day brought in trash that totaled more than an adult elephant!

image:image.image:title: Clean Community Blog - What can be recycled elsewhere in the community?
image:image.image:caption: Depending on the type of paint and quantity, if 5 gallons or less, water based paint, and the paint has been solidified and dried with kitty litter, dirt or sand it may be taken to a convenience center. If any other type of paint or quantity, it must be disposed of at the next HHW collection. Clean Harbors in West Point accepts paint, however there is a fee.

image:image.image:title: Clean Community Blog - What can be recycled elsewhere in the community? - They have a fully trained, licensed, and insured staff. Pricing is based on how much space items take up in our truck. The price that we provide on-site is the maximum price that the customer should expect to pay unless items are added that were not included in the original estimate. If the items take up less space in the truck than estimated, then the customer will only pay for the space used.
